message.content: We are given that $x = 2$, so we substitute into the first equation of the system to get $6 + y = a$. We substitute into the second equation to get $4 + 5y = 2a$. Multiplying the second equation by $3$ gives $12 + 15y = 6a$. Subtracting the first equation, $6 + y = a$ from the third equation, $12 + 15y = 6a$, we get $6 + 14y = 6a - a$, or $14y = 5a - 6$. If $(x,y)$ is a solution to this system, then substituting $x = 2$ and $y = \tfrac{5a - 6}{14}$ into the second equation in the system should give an equation that is true (i.e., the two sides of the equation will be equal). We compute: $$2(2) + 5 \cdot \frac{5a - 6}{14} = 2(2) + \frac{25a - 30}{7} = 4 + \frac{25a - 30}{7} = \frac{28 + 25a - 30}{7} = \frac{25a - 2}{7}.$$This equation is equal to $2a$, the right side of the equation $2x + 5y = 2a$, so we have $$\frac{25a - 2}{7} = 2a.$$Multiplying both sides by $7$ gives $25a - 2 = 14a$, so $11a = 2$, or $a = \boxed{\tfrac{2}{11}}$.
